answer:
**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**  
• **Frame 1 & 2:** You can see the barrels and wide white diagonal markings in the left‐most portion, but no explicit “No Left Turn” sign. Meanwhile, the center of the intersection ahead is filled with construction barrels/cones.  
• **Frame 3:** The cones become more apparent. They stretch across the middle lanes, indicating that going straight through is likely blocked. There is still apparent open space on the far left (potentially a ramp or turn) and on the far right.  
• **Frame 4 & 5:** The row of cones fully occupies the central lanes up ahead. Traffic is funneled either left or right, but not straight forward; there is no direct through‐lane open beyond the intersection.

**Contextual Reasoning**  
All five frames show a consistent cone setup closing off the through‐lanes. Although there is a “One Way” sign overhead, it does not equate to a no‐left‐turn prohibition. No signage forbids a right turn, and the right lane remains open. By contrast, the cones clearly barricade any attempt to continue straight.

**Match to Answer Choices**  
• (A) Straight – Coned off, blocked.  
• (B) Left – Not obviously prohibited (no “No Left Turn” sign and a usable path appears open).  
• (C) Right – Not blocked.  
• (D) None of the above – Incorrect, since going straight is in fact blocked.

**Provide the Best Answer**  
<answer>A</answer>
